label: Letter from Armant Legendre, October 12, 1944
description: Letter from Armant Legendre to his brother, Sidney Legendre, regarding his release from Navy service.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Armant Legendre to his brother, Sidney Legendre, regarding his release from Navy service.

metadata.label: Access Note

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
U. S. S. CASTOR		Thursday , Oct 12 th. 1944.
Lt.Comdr.S.J.Legendre,USNR.
149 East 73 rd. St. 
New York City. 
Dear Droopy Eyes-
Just a few minutes ago the mail-man brings me
your letter of Oct 2 nd, and also one from the Fuhrer dated
Sept 30 th , written from Pearl before you took off for the US.
It so happened that only yesterday I had written a lenghthy
masterpiece to the Fuhrer requesting his noble assistance in
getting to hell out of the Navy. I sent my letter to Box 163,
but figuring that you both might have left, I put on the envelope
"Please forward". But knowing that wild and wooly office of
yours where everybody sits in each others laps, I fear me that
my letter may never be forwarded. So just to be on the safe side, 
I'm enclosing a copy of my letter herewith, also copy of my
"request" and the Bureaus answer.
In Morrises letter, he didnt give me his address in the US,
so I dont know if he will be in Washington, Summerville or New
York. On the other hand, since you have given me the above definite
address [ by the way what is it --- still the old Sanford house ?]
I think best to send to you this enclosed copy. If you feel in
a Boy Scout mood and wish to do your "good deed" , you might
rush down to Washington and haldle this for Arms Arman. Otherwise
,please forward it on to the Fuhrer for his masterfull handling.
when I wrote this letter yesterday, I said on Page 2 
paragraph 3 , that I was still in an "intraining" status and
hoped that the Captain would leave me so. Unfortunately , today
he just told me that he can no longer delay action on his request
for me to be made officially the Exec. He is writing the Bureau
accordingly by todays mail. I only hope that his letter takes as
long to get there as it did the Bureaus reply to reach me--one
month ! Anyway, no time is to be lost , as my chances of being
released will be much less after I'm officially the Exec. So
please Sid , either you or Morris see hat you can do next time
are in Washington. 
If you have a chance when you are in Washington , please
go to Foxcroft and see my little angels. I know that they would
love to see you. Olive writes me that Mimi has been elected Head
of the entire Student Body and Kafrum was elected representative
from her own class. I'm so proud of em that I could pop. If you
do get to see them , give them both a swift kick in their fannies
from their old man.
So long Sid , and let me hear from you when you have a
chance and let me know your own plans. Lord knows when we will
into each other again, as looks like we are out here now
for many moons. My blessings on the Wise Men of Ala Waie
Arma Arma
Lt.Comdr.A.Legendre,USNR
